titleStmt.title: [Detail of map indicating the Overhill Cherokee Village of Tomotley] / [John Gerrard William De Brahm] : a machine-readable transcription

availability.p: This work is the property of the McClung Museum, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN. It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text.

bibl.title: [Detail of map indicating the Overhill Cherokee Village of Tomotley] / [John Gerrard William De Brahm]
bibl.note: This is a photograph of John Gerrard William De Brahm's map detail of the area of the Little Tennessee River Valley containing the Overhill Cherokee village of Tomotley. De Brahm spent time in Tomotley as the guest of Chief Ostenaco in 1756 and contributed to the design and building of Fort Loudoun, 1756-1759. In 1773 DeBrahm completed his "Report of the General Survey in the Southern District of North America" which includes information he gathered about the Cherokees while he lived among them.
Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

projectDesc.p: Prepared for The University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with Microsoft Word spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points

figure.figDesc: Detail of John Gerrard William De Brahm's map of an area of the Little Tennessee River Valley, showing the Overhill Cherokee Village of Tomotley. De Brahm stayed here as a guest of Chief Ostenaco in 1756. De Brahm was a British military engineer who contributed to the design of Ft. Loudoun, 1756-1759. This map is published in DeVorsey, L. Jr. 1971. DeBrahm's Report of the Great Survey in the General Survey in the Southern District of North America, University of South Carolina Press, Columbia, SC. This information was provided by the Frank H. McClung Museum.

p.note: This document consists of one image only.
